00020 /**
00021 
00022 @page bootloader OCTEON Bootloader
00023 
00024 The OCTEON SDK uses version 2013.07 of the opensource U-boot bootloader.
00025 The version included has been modified to support multicore OCTEON processors.
00026 The 'bootoct' command has been added, which supports the booting of an
00027 OCTEON executive application, and the 'bootoctlinux' has been added to boot
00028 a Linux kernel.  More information about U-boot is
00029 available on the U-boot project page at
00030 http://www.denx.de/wiki/U-Boot and in the directory sdk/docs/u-boot.
00031 Also see the README file included with U-Boot as well as the documentation
00032 in the U-Boot doc directory.
00033 
00034 
00035     - @ref usage
00036     - @ref octeon_specific
00037     - @ref memory_map
00038     - @ref boot_process
00039     - @ref building_u-boot
00040     - @ref updating_u-boot
00041     - @ref board_support
00042     - @ref se_api
00043     - @ref limitations
00044     - @ref serial_config
00045     - @ref console_config
00046     - @ref u-boot_applications
00047 
00048 @section usage Usage
00049 
00050 The bootloader supports loading multiple application images on subsets of
00051 cores.  The applications are started when the application that runs on
00052 core 0 is loaded, so this application should be loaded last.
00053 
00054 
00055 On the simulator, the bootloader is
00056 automatically invoked by the 'oct-sim' script, which should be used to run
00057 the simulator.  Boot commands and application arguments are passed to the
00058 bootloader through an environment file using the '-envfile' option on the oct-sim script.
00059 
00060 
00061 On hardware the bootloader provides an interactive prompt for setting
00062 environment variables and issuing commands.
00063 
00064 The 'bootoct' command has been added to support the multicore OCTEON
00065 executive environment.  The stack and heap sizes are configurable at runtime, and are controlled
00066 by providing arguments to the bootoct command.
00067 The bootoct command usage is:
00068 
00069 @verbatim
00070 bootoct [ elf_address [stack=stack_size] [heap=heap_size] [coremask=mask_to_run | numcores=core_cnt_to_run] [forceboot] [debug] [break] [endbootargs] [app_name] [app_args ...]
00071     elf-address:    address of ELF image to load. defaults to $(loadaddr). If 0, default load address used.
00072     stack:          size of stack in bytes.  Default is 1 megabyte
00073     heap:           size of heap in bytes.   Default is 3 megabytes
00074     coremask:       mask of cores to run on.  Anded with coremask_override
00075                     environment variable to ensure only working cores are used.
00076                     In a multi-node configuration the coremask for each
00077                     node should be separated by a comma.  For example, to use
00078                     four cores on node 0 and 8 cores on node 1 the coremask
00079                     value should be set to 0xf,0xff.
00080     numcores:       number of cores to run on.  Runs on specified number of
00081                     cores, taking into account the coremask_override.  On a
00082                     multi-node configuration, the number of cores for nodes 0
00083                     and 1 are separated by a comma.  For example, to use 4 cores
00084                     on node 0 and 8 cores on node 1 the parameter would be 4,8.
00085     skipcores:      only meaningful with numcores.  Skips this many cores
00086                     (starting from 0) when loading the numcores cores.  For
00087                     example, setting skipcores to 1 will skip core 0.
00088                     and load the application starting at the next available core.
00089                     On a multi-node configuration the number of cores to skip
00090                     for each node is separated by a comma like the numcores
00091                     parameter.
00092     debug:          if present, bootloader passes debug flag to application which will cause
00093                     the application to stop at a breakpoint on startup.
00094     break:          if present, exit program when control-c is received on the console.
00095     forceboot:      if set, boots application even if core 0 is not in mask
00096     endbootargs:    if set, bootloader does not process any further arguments and only passes
00097                     the arguments that follow to the application.  If not set, the application
00098                     gets the entire commnad line as arguments.
00099     app name:       U-boot has no way of knowing the name of the application so this must be the first argument.
00100 
00101 @endverbatim
00102 
00103 The 'bootoctlinux' command has been added to support booting the Linux kernel.  The bootoctlinux command usage is:
00104 
00105 @verbatim
00106 bootoctlinux elf_address [coremask=mask_to_run | numcores=core_cnt_to_run] [forceboot] [skipcores=core_cnt_to_skip] [namedblock=name] [endbootargs] [...]
00107     elf_address:    address of ELF image to load. If 0, default load address
00108                     is  used.
00109     coremask:       mask of cores to run on.  Anded with coremask_override environment
00110                     variable to ensure only working cores are used.
00111                     On a multi-node configuration the coremask for each node
00112                     should be separated by a comma.  For example, to run 4 cores
00113                     on node 0 and 8 cores on node 1 the coremask should be set
00114                     to 0xf,0xff.
00115     numcores:       number of cores to run on.  Runs on specified number of
00116                     cores, taking into account the coremask_override.  On a
00117                     multi-node configuration the number of cores for each node
00118                     is separated by a comma.  For example, to run 4 cores on
00119                     node 0 and 8 cores on node 1 the parameter would be 4,8.
00120     skipcores:      only meaningful with numcores.  Skips this many cores
00121                     (starting from 0) when loading the numcores cores.  For
00122                     example, setting skipcores to 1 will skip core 0.
00123                     and load the application starting at the next available core.
00124                     On a multi-node configuration the number of cores to skip
00125                     for each node should be separated by a comma like the
00126                     numcores parameter.
00127     forceboot:      if set, boots application even if core 0 is not in mask
00128     namedblock      specifies a named block to load the kernel
00129     endbootargs:    if set, bootloader does not process any further arguments and only passes
00130                     the arguments that follow to the application.  If not set, the application
00131                     gets the entire commnad line as arguments.
00132 
00133 @endverbatim
00134 
00135 
00136 The 'bootoctelf' command has been added to support booting the ELF images
00137 such as VxWorks images.  The ELF entry point is branched to from the
00138 bootloader, so the ELF image must contain all its own startup code.  This
00139 is intented for use with other operating systems.  The OCTEON SDK does not
00140 produce any ELF images suitable for use with this command.
00141 The bootoct command usage is:
00142 
00143 @verbatim
00144 bootoctelf elf_address mem_size [coremask=mask_to_run] [forceboot]
00145     elf_address:    address of ELF image to load. If 0, default load address is
00146                     used.
00147     mem_size:       amount of memory to reserve for ELF file.  Starts at ELF
00148                     entry point rounded down to 1 MByte alignment.
00149                     No memory allocated if not specified.  (Program will not
00150                     coexist with simple executive applications or Linux if memory
00151                     is not allocated properly.
00152 
00153     coremask:       mask of cores to run on.  Anded with coremask_override
00154                     environment variable to ensure only working cores are used.
00155                     Note: Most ELF files are only suitable for booting on a
00156                     single core.
00157                     On a multi-node configuration the coremask values are
00158                     separated by a comma for each node.  For example, on a
00159                     two-node 78xx system the coremask value might be
00160                     0xf,0xff to run 4 cores on node 0 and 8 cores on node 1.
00161     forceboot:      if set, boots application even if core 0 is not in mask
00162     numcores        number of cores to run on.  Runs on specified number of
00163                     cores, taking into account the coremask_override.  In
00164                     a multi-node setup a comma should be used to specify the
00165                     number of cores to use on each node.  For example, to use
00166                     4 cores on node 0 and 8 cores on node 1 the parameter should
00167                     be 4,8.
00168     skipcores       only meaningful with numcores.  Skips this many cores
00169                     (starting from 0) when loading the numcores cores.
00170                     For example, setting skipcores to 1 will skip core 0
00171                     and load the application starting at the next available core.
00172                     On a dual-node configuration the number of cores to skip
00173                     for each node should be separated by a comma.
00174 
00175 @endverbatim
00176 
00177 Starting in 2.1, the 'octreginfo' command has been added to print out all of the CP0 registers
00178 as well as any TLB entries in use. It is a subset of the oct-remote-core utility.  It currently takes no parameters.
00179 
00180 The tlv_eeprom command allows you to read and optionally set various parameters
00181 stored in the board serial EEPROM.
00182 
00183 @verbatim
00184 tlv_eeprom [display|set|delete|help]
00185 tlv_eeprom display
00186        - display contents of eeprom data structures
00187 tlv_eeprom set
00188        - set contents of eeprom data structures, values in hex or decimal
00189        set clock <ddr_clock in Mhz> <cpu_ref_clock in Mhz * 8> <dfa_ref_cloc
00190 k in Mhz * 8> <spi_clock in Mhz> (CN3XXX/CN5XXX)
00191        set board <board type> <major rev> <minor rev>  <serial string>
00192        set mac    <mac base x:x:x:x:x:x> <mac addr count>
00193        set voltmult <voltage in millivolts> <cpu multiplier> (CN3XXX/CN5XXX)
00194        set volt <core voltage in millivolts> (CN6XXX/CNF7XXX/CN7XXX)
00195        set mult <cpu multiplier> <IO multiplier> (CN6XXX/CNF7XXX/CN7XXX)
00196        set ddrclock <ddr clock Hz> (CN6XXX/CNF7XXX/CN7XXX)
00197        set ddrverbose <verbosity> Sets the DDR verbosity during DDR 
00198            initialization, 0 for none.
00199              bit 0: DDR verbose output
00200              bit 1: DDR trace output
00201              bit 2: DDR debug output
00202        set capability [coremask_override]
00203 tlv_eeprom delete <tuple addr>
00204        - deletes tuple at address and compacts any following tuples.
00205 
00206 Chip types have been deprecated, and can no longer be set.
00207 
00208 (use tlv_eeprom help for list of board types)
00209 
00210 @endverbatim
00211 
00212 The namedalloc command allocates a named block of memory.  It also sets the environment variables
00213 named_block_addr and named_block_size to the address and size of the last allocated block.  The namedfree
00214 command is used to free blocks allocated with namedalloc and namedprint will print all named blocks.
00215 
00216 @verbatim
00217 namedalloc name size [address]
00218     - Allocate a named bootmem block with a given name and size at an
00219       optional fixed address.  Sets environment variables named_block_addr,
00220       named_block_size to address and size of block allocated.
00221 
00222 namedfree name
00223     - Free a named bootmem block_address
00224 
00225 namedprint
00226     - Print list of named bootmem blocks
00227 @endverbatim
00228 
00229 Starting in 2.1, the 'flush_l2c', 'flush_dcache' and 'inv_icache' commands have been added.
00230 These flush the L2 cache, data cache and invalidate the instruction cache respectively.  None of these
00231 commands take any parameters.
00232 
00233 Starting in 2.1, the octwd command can start and stop watchdog timer support within U-Boot.
00234 By default the watchdog is disabled unless the enable_watchdog environment variable is set.
00235 
00236 @verbatim
00237 octwd - Starts the OCTEON watchdog
00238 
00239 Usage:
00240 octwd Usage:
00241 octwd start [timeout in ms] - initializes and starts the watchdog
00242 octwd stop                  - disables the watchdog timer
00243 @endverbatim
00244 
00245 Starting in 2.1, the 'sata' command has been added with initial support for Silicon Image PCIe SATA
00246 controllers.  Sata can now be used in commands like fatls and ext2load just like ide and usb can be used.
00247 NOTE: This command requires that SATA support is enabled and compiled for a particular board.  It may not
00248 be available on all boards.
00249 
00250 @verbatim
00251 sata - SATA sub system
00252 
00253 Usage:
00254 sata init - init SATA sub system
00255 sata info - show available SATA devices
00256 sata device [dev] - show or set current device
00257 sata part [dev] - print partition table
00258 sata read addr blk# cnt
00259 sata write addr blk# cnt
00260 @endverbatim
00261 
00262 <h3> Simulator specific usage</h3>
00263 
00264 To change the arguments provided to the bootoct command during
00265 simulator, an alternate u-boot environment file that specifies
00266 an alternate default boot command needs to be created.  Multiple commands
00267 can be specified,
00268 with a semicolon (;) used as a separator.  To change the stack and heap
00269 sizes, an environment file with the following content should be created:
00270 
00271 @verbatim
00272 bootcmd=bootoct 0x10000000 stack=0x34500 heap=0x567800
00273 @endverbatim
00274 
00275 This file is then passed to the bootloader by passing the filename
00276 with the oct-sim option '-envfile=env_file_name".  Please refer to the
00277 simulator documentation for more information on oct-sim and simulator
00278 options. The 'application-args' example shows how to pass arguments to
00279 applications as well as how to specify different stack and heap sizes.
00280 The oct-sim script accepts arguments for stack/heap sizes as well as
00281 application arguments, and creates the environment file on the fly.
00282 Please see the simulator documentation and the 'application-args'
00283 example for more information.
00284 
00285 To run multiple applications the other application ELF files must be
00286 loaded into the boot bus (0x10000000 - 0x1fffffff) with the -ld option,
00287 and the corresponding bootoct command must be added to the environment
00288 file.
00289 For example, the following command and environment file will load app1 on
00290 cores 0-3, and app2 on cores 4-7:
00291 
00292 @verbatim
00293 oct-sim app1 -ld0x11000000:app2 -quiet -noperf -numcores=8 -envfile=myenv
00294 @endverbatim
00295 
00296 The 'myenv' file should contain:
00297 @verbatim
00298 bootcmd=bootoct 0x11000000 coremask=0xf0;bootoct 0x10000000 coremask=0xf
00299 @endverbatim
00300 
00301 The bootloader boots the loaded application(s) when core 0 is in the coremask
00302 of loaded application.  This means that when loading multiple application images
00303 the image running on core 0 must be loaded last.
00304 
00305 
00306 <h3> Remote boot mode </h3>
00307 
00308 OCTEON supports booting over PCI with the help of a PCI host or over
00309 EJTAG. The board must be configured to be a PCI target and to be in PCI
00310 boot mode for PCI boot.  For EJTAG remote boot, the OCTEON must _not_ be
00311 in PCI boot mode. In PCI boot mode no cores come out of reset when the
00312 chip is reset.  The procedure is as follows:
00313  - Host program configures DRAM controller on OCTEON
00314  - Host program copies bootloader to DRAM
00315  - Host program configures MIO local memory block to be at reset vector,
00316    and copies instructions to branch to the bootloader image in DRAM to
00317    the local memory.
00318  - Host program takes core 0 out of reset.  Core 0 fetches instructions
00319    from the reset vector - these are supplied from the MIO local memory
00320    block, no memory is required on the boot bus.
00321  - The instructions in this
00322    local memory jump to the bootloader image already present in OCTEON
00323    DRAM, and the bootloader boots from that location.
00324 
00325 The 'oct-remote-boot' program in the host/remote-utils directory implements the host
00326 portion of the PCI boot process.  The u-boot image determines that it is
00327 booting from RAM, and changes its behavior as follows:
00328  - the bootloader skips DRAM controller setup.
00329 
00330 
00331 <h3> Networking support (DHCP, TFTP) </h3>
00332 
00333 U-boot supports DHCP and TFTP using OCTEON's GMX, MIX, BGX interfaces. These
00334 features require properly configured TFTP and DHCP servers to be available.  The
00335 network interface to use for networking is selected by the ethact environment
00336 variable. The ethact environment variable is initialized to the value of the
00337 ethprime environment variable first.  The ethact environment variable is not
00338 persistent whereas the ethprime environment variable is.
00339  
00340 If the environment variable "netsingle" is set then DHCP will not attempt to go
00341 to the next interface if the first interface fails.
00342 
00343 Relevant commands:
00344  - dhcp: Use this command to get an IP address, netmask, server address, boot file, and
00345         boot command.  The boot file is automatically loaded via tftp unless
00346     the 'autoload' environment variable is set to 'n'.  The boot command is put
00347     into the 'NetOurBootCommand' environment variable.
00348     Note that the boot command is not a standard DHCP field,
00349     see below for details.
00350 
00351     The NetOurBootCommand feature is not enabled by default.  In order to
00352     enable it, a board configuration file must define the following three
00353     options:
00354 
00355         CONFIG_BOOTP_VENDOREX - enable vendor specific extensions
00356         CONFIG_BOOTP_VENDOREX_OPTIONS - enable vendor specific options
00357         CONFIG_OCTEON_NET_OUR_BOOT_COMMAND - enables option 224
00358 
00359  - cdp: Use this command to get an IP address and netmask vis Cisco Discover Protocol.
00360  - tftpboot:  This command loads the requested file via the tftp protocol.  This command
00361     will use the default load address (loadaddr) and the filename in the bootfile environment
00362     variable if not arguments are specified.  This command expects the
00363     ipaddr, netmask, and serverip environment variables to be set.
00364  - ping: Transmits an ICMP echo request.  Note that u-boot only listens for
00365    networking traffic when it is expecting some, so u-boot will not respond to
00366    pings.
00367  - nfs: This command loads the specified file via the NFS protocol.
00368 
00369 <h4> MDIO Support </h4>
00370 It is possible to access PHY registers for reading and writing inside U-Boot.
00371 The mdio command supports both clause 22 and clause 45.
00372 
00373 For example, to read clause 45 register 0x1e.0xe000 on the phy connected to
00374 octeth0 the following command will work:
00375 @verbatim
00376 mdio read octeth0 0x1e.0xe000
00377 @endverbatim
00378 For a clause 22 register the command would be something like:
00379 @verbatim
00380 mdio read octeth0 0x1e
00381 @endverbatim
00382 The mdio command also supports ranges.  For example, to read 16 registers
00383 the following command will work:
00384 @verbatim
00385 mdio read octeth0 1.0x0-0x10
00386 @endverbatim
00387 
00388 <h4> Autobooting a TFTP loaded image </h4>
00389 Set the 'bootcmd' environment variable to the boot command that should be run. The following code will
00390 set the boot command to boot the loaded simple executive program on 4 cores.
00391 @verbatim
00392  setenv bootcmd 'dhcp;bootoct $(loadaddr) numcores=4'
00393  saveenv
00394 @endverbatim
00395 The following code will use the boot command provided by DHCP to boot the image.
00396 @verbatim
00397  setenv bootcmd 'dhcp;run $(NetOurBootCommand)'
00398  saveenv
00399 @endverbatim
00400 
00401 
00402 <h4> Boot command via DHCP </h4>
00403 DHCP does not have a standard option field for returning a boot command.  We
00404 use option number 224 to return the boot command to u-boot.  The following configuration
00405 file snippet configures the ISC dhcp server to return the boot command.  Change the
00406 IP addresses and netmasks as appropriate for your network.
00407 @verbatim
00408 option octeon-boot-command code 224 = string;
00409 
00410 subnet 192.168.2.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 {
00411   range 192.168.2.100 192.168.2.200;
00412   option octeon-boot-command "bootoct $(loadaddr) numcores=4";
00413   filename "octeon_boot_file";
00414   server-name "192.168.2.1";
00415   next-server 192.168.2.1;
00416 }
00417 @endverbatim
00418 
00419 
00420 
00421 
00422 <h3> Application considerations </h3>
00423 
00424 The bootloader supports loading multiple applications on subsets of
00425 cores.  This is primarily useful for running a simple executive
00426 application and Linux at the same time.   It is recommended that a
00427 single simple executive image be run on all cores, and that the
00428 application handle core dependent processing if necessary.  Additionally,
00429 the following should be kept in mind:
00430 - global (and static) data is copied for each core, unless it is read only.  If large
00431 amounts of data are compiled in to the application, make it 'const'
00432 (readonly) if possible.  This allows one copy of the data to be shared by
00433 all cores.
00434 
00435 @section octeon_specific  OCTEON specific added functionality
00436 
00437 <h3> Named bootmem blocks </h3>
00438 
00439 The bootloader uses the bootmem allocator to allocate physical memory for
00440 its own use, and passes the bootmem descriptor to the application so that
00441 the application can manage the memory remaining after application loading.
00442 Named bootmem blocks are memory blocks allocated with the bootmem allocator
00443 that have names associated with them in table in the bootmem descriptor.  This
00444 allows the bootloader to allocate memory blocks for various purposes assign
00445 names that the application can use to reference them.  For example, named bootmem
00446 blocks could be used to have the bootloader load a DFA graph from a compact flash card
00447 into a named block and then have the application load the graph from that block.
00448 
00449 Three new bootloader commands have been added to support this functionality.  (Executive
00450 functions have also been added - see the executive documentation for more information.)
00451 
00452 - namedalloc @<block_name> @<block_size> [block_address]
00453      - This command allocates a named block of a given name and size at an optional address.
00454      If the name or memory block is not available, this command fails.  The environment variables
00455      named_block_addr and named_block_size are set when allocation is successful, and can be used
00456      other commands.
00457 - namedfree @<block_name>
00458      - Frees block with supplied name name.
00459 - namedprint
00460     - Prints a list of current named blocks.
00461 
00462 <h3> Support for Gzip Compressed Images</h3>
00463 
00464 The bootloader has a command @b unzip for uncompressing Gzipped images from
00465 memory. The unzip command can read its input from fixed address. Output is written to a specific
00466 address. It is the user's responsibility to make sure the output region is
00467 large enough. The command syntax is:
00468 
00469 @verbatim
00470     unzip srcaddr dstaddr [dstsize]
00471 @endverbatim
00472 
00473 
00474 <h3> Environment variables</h3>
00475 A number of special environment variables have been added (or usage modified) to make u-boot more configurable.  These variables
00476 are stored in the u-boot environment (typically in flash), and are updated using the setenv and savenv commands.
00477 
00478 <b> Special note on environment variable expansion for compound commands: </b>  U-boot expands all environment variables in a command
00479 (compound or not) before any of the commands are executed.  This means that a compound command like:
00480 
00481 @verbatim
00482 dhcp;tftp 0x20000000 elf.bin;bootoct $(fileaddr)
00483 @endverbatim
00484 
00485 will not work becuase the fileaddr environment variable is expanded before the tftp command runs and sets it.  A command like this
00486 should be written in one of the following ways:
00487 
00488 @verbatim
00489 dhcp;tftp 0x20000000 elf.bin;bootoct 0x20000000
00490 dhcp;tftp;bootoct $(loadaddr)
00491 @endverbatim
00492 The first example uses a fixed address for both the tftp and bootoct command.  The second uses the default load address for the tftp, and then specifies
00493 the default load address to the bootoct command.
00494 
00495 - @b baudrate Controls the baudrate of the console uart
00496 - @b boardname Name of the board.  This is set automatically.
00497 - @b board_revision Revision number of the board.  This is required for the
00498   ebb7800, ebb7804 and the tb7600 board with pass 1.0 CN7800 or pass 1.0 CN7600
00499   devices since otherwise there is no way to determine the board revision.
00500 - @b console_uart Selects which uart (0 or 1) to use for the console.  This is passed to simple executive applications which will use the same
00501   uart for the console.  Defaults to 0.  Changes to this variable take effect immediately (as of SDK 1.6.0)
00502 - @b coremask_override This defines the working cores for the OCTEON on the board.  This is primarily used for engineering samples, as production
00503   parts have this set in silicon, and this variable reflects that value.
00504 - @b disable_cf_dma If defined (any value), DMA will not be used for the compactflash interface.
00505 - @b disable_dfm If defined (any value) the DFM module will not be initialized.  This may result in traps in Simple Executive applications.
00506 - @b disable_l2_index_aliasing If defined (any value), L2 Cache index aliasing is disabled.
00507 - @b disable_mmc If defined (any value) then MMC devices will not be initialized.
00508 - @b disable_nand If defined (any value) then NAND flash will not be initialized.
00509 - @b disable_networking If defined (any value), no OCTEON network support is enabled in the bootloader.  This has no effect on applications.
00510 - @b disable_spi If defined (any value), all SPI interfaces are ignored by the blootloader.  This has no effect on applications.
00511 - @b disable_spi_ixf18201 If defined (any value), all SPI interfaces connected to a IXF18201 are disabled.  This does not affect the SPI4000.
00512 - @b disable_usb_scan Disables USB initialization and scanning during boot-up.  USB can be started later via the usb command.
00513 - @b ddr_clock_hertz Overrides the DDR clock stored in the EEPROM.
00514 - @b ddr_narrow Force the DDR interface to be 'narrow'.  Most OCTEONs support 2 DDR interface widths, and this forces the chip to use the narrower of the two.
00515 - @b ddr_ref_hertz Overrides the DDR reference clock.
00516 - @b ddr_safe (must be yes) If set to 'yes', then more conservative DDR2 timings are used.
00517 - @b disable_spi Disables SPI interface initialization and support.
00518 - @b ddr_trace_init Turns on tracing of all DDR operations during initialization.
00519 - @b ddr_verbose If set to 'yes', then detailed DDR2 configuration information is displayed at boot.  This variable _must_ be set for other
00520   ddr controller environment variables to be checked.  Please refer to the dram controller initialization code for details on which parameters can
00521   be adjusted with environment variables.
00522 - @b dram_size_mbytes Forces U-Boot to override the amount of memory detected and used.
00523 - @b download_baudrate Controls the baudrate for downloads when using the
00524 loadb command. This allows different baudrates to be used for console and
00525 downloading.
00526 - @b enable_spi_ixf18201 - If defined (any value) then boards that support a SPI IXF18201 interface will initialize it even if disable_spi is also set. This is used for the NICPro2 board which disables this by default.
00527 - @b enable_spi_eeprom - Enables the SPI connected EEPROM on EBB6100 evaluation boards, otherwise the SLIC interfaces are enabled.
00528 - @b enable_usb_ehci_clock - Initializes the USB clock and runs the BIST test if disable_usb_scan is set, otherwise the USB clock and BIST test will not be run.
00529 - @b enable_watchdog - Enables the hardware watchdog timer if set.  Also see the watchdog_timeout environment variable.
00530 - @b ethact Current active Ethernet interface.  Note that this is NOT persistent, use ethprime instead to save.
00531 - @b ethprime First Ethernet interface to use for ethact.  This is persistent.
00532 - @b fileaddr  Address that a file/image was loaded at using the loadb, fatload, ext2load, or tftp commands.
00533 - @b icache_prefetch_disable  Disable instruction cache prefetching support for Linux and simple executive applications.
00534 - @b limit_dram_mbytes Limits the DRAM size to the specified number of MBytes.  This is useful for testing small memory configurations
00535 on boards that have move memory.  Both the bootloader and any loaded apps are affected by this limit.
00536 - @b limit_l2_ways Limits the L2 to the specified number of ways (associations) when defined.  Valid values are between
00537 1 and (num_ways - 1).
00538 - @b loadaddr Indicates the current default load address for load commands.  This is set  at boot time based on the memory allocated by the octeon_reserved_mem_load*
00539   variables.  If the reserved memory for loading is disabled, then this variable will keep its value across boots. (New in SDK 1.6.0)
00540   NOTE:  If memory is reserved for loading, this variable should not be changed directly - the reserved memory for loading should be adjusted instead.
00541   If no memory is reserved for loading, then and only then should this variable be directly changed.
00542 - @b mmc_max_freq This will override the maximum frequency supported by the MMC device in Hz.
00543 - @b mmc_voltages This is used to override the supported voltages reported to the MMC card.  Do not set this.
00544 - @b mtdids This environment variable defines the mapping from u-boot device names to linux kernel device names.  This allows the same 'mtdparts' definition
00545   to be shared between Linux and u-boot even if different device names are used.  This environment variable must be of the form
00546  "<u-boot_name>=<linux_name>,<u-boot_name>=<linux_name>,...".  The Linux names are used in the mtdparts environment variable, allowing this environment variable
00547  to be passed directly to Linux.  For OCTEON boards, nand devices are named "nandX", where X is a digit. (The first NAND device is nand0.)
00548 @verbatim
00549 mtdids=<idmap>[,<idmap>,...]
00550 
00551 <idmap>    := <dev-id>=<mtd-id>
00552 <dev-id>   := 'octeon_nand'<dev-num>|'nor'<dev-num>
00553 <dev-num>  := mtd device number, 0...
00554 <mtd-id>   := unique device tag used by linux kernel to find mtd device (mtd->name)
00555 @endverbatim
00556 - @b mtdparts This environment defines the MTD partitioning of flash devices, and is meant to be shared with the Linux kernel.  As such, it has "mtdparts=" as the beginning
00557   of the expected value of the variable, so that $(mtdparts) can be passed on the Linux command line and have the expected form.  This environment uses the Linux device names defined
00558   in the mtdids variable.
00559 @verbatim
00560 mtdparts=mtdparts=<mtd-def>[;<mtd-def>...]
00561 
00562 <mtd-def>  := <mtd-id>:<part-def>[,<part-def>...]
00563 <mtd-id>   := unique device tag used by linux kernel to find mtd device (mtd->name)
00564 <part-def> := <size>[@<offset>][<name>][<ro-flag>]
00565 <size>     := standard linux memsize OR '-' to denote all remaining space
00566 <offset>   := partition start offset within the device
00567 <name>     := '(' NAME ')'
00568 <ro-flag>  := when set to 'ro' makes partition read-only (not used, passed to kernel)
00569 @endverbatim
00570 - @b named_block_addr Set to the address of the last named block allocated with the namedalloc command.
00571 - @b named_block_size Set to the size of the last named block allocated with the namedalloc command.
00572 - @b nand_ecc_mode Overrides the ECC mode for NAND flash.  Currently soft_bch, soft and none are supported.
00573 - @b nand_ecc_size specifies how many bytes per block of ECC to provide if nand_ecc_mode is soft_bch.
00574 - @b no_mark_private_data If defined (any value), the bootloader will not mark the private data for simple executive applications as special for use
00575   with the syncws instruction.
00576 - @b octeon_debug_nand Set to display a lot of debugging information when performing NAND flash operations.
00577 - @b octeon_failsafe_mode Set to 1 if running in failsafe mode, otherwise set to 0.
00578 - @b octeon_load_app_hi If defined (any value), the bootloader will preferentially allocate memory from the DDR1 ranged (0x410000000 - 0x420000000)
00579   when loading simple executive applications.
00580 - @b octeon_mmc_ddr Set to 1 to enable double data rate or 0 to disable.  Enabled if not set.
00581 - @b octeon_ram_mode Set to 1 if U-Boot was booted out of RAM, otherwise set to 0.
00582 - @b octeon_reserved_mem_linux_base Base address for linux reserved memory.  The octeon_reserved_mem_linux_size variable must be set for this to take effect.
00583 - @b octeon_reserved_mem_linux_size Size of memory reserved for linux image in bytes.  This reserved memory block ensures that no allocations
00584   conflict with the range required by Linux before the kernel is loaded.  This is freed when a linux image is loaded, or when the application starts
00585   if a linux image is not loaded.  If set to 0, this region is not reserved.  If not set, compile time defaults are used for size and address.
00586 - @b octeon_reserved_mem_load_base Base address of bootloader reserved memory. The octeon_reserved_mem_load_size variable must be set for this to take effect.
00587 - @b octeon_reserved_mem_load_size Specifies the size (in bytes) of the memory reserved for the loading of applications by the bootloader.  This
00588   defaults to 0x100000 - 0x1000000 (for SDK 1.6.0 and earlier) (default for SDK 1.7.0 will to auto placement based on memory size),
00589   and is used for temporary storage of the ELF files when loaded off of compact flash or tftp.  This memory
00590   is freed when the application is booted.  If set to 0, this region is not reserved.  If not set, compile time defaults are used for size and address.
00591 - @b octeon_stage3_bootloader Specifies the filename of the stage 3 bootloader
00592   when booting from eMMC.
00593 - @b octeon_stage3_devname Specifies the name of the device to load the bootloader
00594   from.  Typically this will be "mmc".
00595 - @b octeon_stage3_devno Specifies the device number used for loading the stage 3
00596   bootloader when booting from eMMC or NAND.
00597 - @b octeon_stage3_failsafe_bootloader Specifies the filename of the stage 3
00598   failsafe bootloader.
00599 - @b octeon_stage3_load_addr Specifies the address where the stage 3 bootloader
00600   will be loaded in memory and executed from.
00601 - @b octeon_usb_tune This sets a couple of tuning parameters that might help with several boards and chips if EHCI timeout
00602 errors occur.
00603 - @b pci_console_active If defined (any value), the PCI console mode is active.  (See PCI console section in PCI target documentation
00604 for more detail on PCI console.) Note that the output of U-Boot will hang after the output buffer fills if no PCI console is connected.
00605 - @b pci_console_count Specifies the number of PCI console channels.
00606 - @b pci_console_size Specifies PCI console buffer size in bytes.
00607 - @b pcieX:Y_lanes Specifies the number of PCIe lanes for QLM X, node Y.
00608 - @b pcieX:Y_mode Specifies the PCIe mode for QLM X, node Y.  Value can be ep or rc.
00609 - @b pcieX_Y_gen Specifies the PCIe generation for QLM X, node Y.  Value can be 1, 2 or 3.
00610 - @b prompt Overrides the default prompt.  Note that a space is always appended.
00611 - @b qlmX:Y_mode Specifies the mode the QLM should operate in.  This is used for
00612      numerous CN78XX based boards.  X specifies the QLM number and Y specifies
00613      the node number.  Valid modes are: none, sgmii, xaui, dxaui, rxaui, ila, ilk,
00614      xlaui, xfi, 10G_KR, 40G_KR, pcie.  Many of these can take an optional parameter
00615      specifying that there is no PHY.  For example, qlm6:0_mode=xlaui,no_phy.
00616 - @b stderr Sets the stderr destinations.  Currently "serial", "pci" and "serial,pci" are supported.
00617 Note: if pci is selected then U-Boot will stop and wait for the PCI console to connect once
00618 the output buffer is full.
00619 - @b stdin Sets the stdin sources.  Currently "serial", "pci" and "bootoct" are supported.
00620   Multiple inputs can be selected, separated by a comma, for example, "serial,pci".
00621 - @b stdout Sets the stdout destinations.  Currently "serial", "pci" and "serial,pci" are supported.
00622   Note: if pci is selected then U-Boot will stop and wait for the PCI console to connect once
00623   the output buffer is full.
00624 - @b usb_host_port Select which OCTEON USB port to use for devices with more than one USB port, such as CN68XX.  Port numbering starts at 0.
00625 - @b vcs8488_preemph Set this to the hex value to override the PHYXS_TYPE_CTRL (PHY XS XAUI TX Pre-emphasis control) register on the Vitesse VCS8488 PHY.
00626 - @b vcs8488_rxeq Set this to the hex value to verride the PHYXS_RXEQ_CTRL (PHY XS XAUI RX Equalization Control) register on the Vitesse VCS8488 PHY.
00627 - @b vcs8488_txdrvctrl1 Set this to the hex value to override the PMA_TXOUTCTRL1 register on the
00628 Vitesse VCS8488 PHY.
00629 - @b vcs8488_txdrvctrl2 Set this to the hex value to override the PMA_TXOUTCTRL2 register on the
00630 Vitesse VCS8488 PHY.
00631 - @b watchdog_enable Set this to enable watchdog support.  By default watchdog support is disabled.
00632 - @b watchdog_timeout Sets the watchdog timeout in ms.  The maximum is 5000ms.  NOTE: enable_watchdog must also be set.
00633 
00634 <h4> Erasing the environment </h4>
00635 
00636 Sometimes it is desirable to erase the entire environment.  The 'eraseenv'
00637 command has been added to facilitate this.  Note that this only works when
00638 the environment is stored in NOR flash.
00639 
00640 <h4> Environment stored in eMMC or a filesystem </h4>
00641 U-Boot now supports loading the environment from eMMC or a file.  When
00642 configured to do this the saveenv command will work as it did before.  One
00643 difference, however, is that the environment is loaded very late in the
00644 boot process after eMMC or USB has been enabled so environment variables that
00645 affect processes early in the boot process will have no effect.
00646 
00647 @section memory_map  Memory map and TLB usage
00648 
00649 
00650 <h3> Physical memory map </h3>
00651 The OCTEON physical memory addressing is as follows (Please see the
00652 hardware manual for more information.):
00653 @verbatim
00654 DDR0: 0x0 0000 0000 to 0x0 0FFF FFFF    (low  256 Megabytes)
00655 DDR1: 0x4 1000 0000 to 0x4 1FFF FFFF    (next 256 Megabytes)
00656 DDR2: 0x0 2000 0000 to 0x3 FFFF FFFF    (next 15.5 Gigabytes)
00657 @endverbatim
00658 
00659 
00660 <h3> Bootloader and OCTEON executive physical memory usage </h3>
00661 
00662 The bootloader uses the address range from 0x0 to 0xFFFFF (low 1 megabyte) for boot time
00663 initialization and exception vectors, debugger stub and debugger state.
00664 The low 1 MByte remains in use after the applications are running. U-boot
00665 allocates a named bootmem block (__uboot_code_data) for its code and data.  This memory
00666 may be freed by the application after the application has started.  This
00667 memory is required for some operations, such as GDB over the UART, and the
00668 'bootoct' linux command.  If either of these features is used, the
00669 bootloader memory must not be freed.
00670 
00671 U-boot creates a global free memory list and allocator (bootmem_alloc*) that it uses to allocate memory for
00672 applications as well as some internal uses (network packet buffers, PCI console buffers.)This memory is managed by the
00673 bootmem allocator in cvmx-bootmem.c. The applications and operating systems should use this allocator
00674 to allocate physical memory.
00675 
00676 <h4> Boot time reserved memory </h4>
00677 The bootloader creates two special reserved memory blocks that are used at boot time to set aside memory for
00678 loading application/OS images and the Linux kernel.  When loading an application from somewhere other than the
00679 bootflash (network, compactflash, etc.) there must be room in memory for the ELF image, as well as room for
00680 the ELF data to be loaded into the memory locations that it will run from.  While it is being loaded, there will
00681 be two copies of the ELF data in memory: one copy in the ELF image(file) itself, and one where the bootloader is
00682 copying it to run from.  Simple executive applications use the TLB for virtual memory mappings, so they do not require
00683 a particular physical location in memory.  The load reserved area must be set aside to ensure that the loading of
00684 (potentially several) applications does not interfere with the load area, and also that the loading of later applications
00685 will not overwrite a previously loaded one.
00686 Linux and other OSes are linked at a specific physical address.  The Linux reserved block keeps this specific physical range
00687 available even if other allocations (for example, loading a simple executive application) is done before it.  The Linux reserved
00688 block is typically only required if Linux is used along with simple executive applications.
00689 
00690 <h5> Default reserved block locations </h5>
00691 <h6>SDK 1.6.X and earlier:</h6>
00692 - The image loading block is from address  0x100000 -  0x1000000
00693 - The linux reserved block is from address 0x1000000 - 0x9000000
00694 
00695 <h6>SDK 1.7.X and SDK 1.9.X:</h6>
00696 - The image loading block is allocated at the base of the DDR2 DRAM segment if there is enough memory, or at the top available
00697   DRAM in the DDR0 segment.  It is sized based on the amount of available
00698   memory.
00699 - The linux reserved block is allocated at 0x100000 and is sized based on
00700   the amount of available memory.
00701 
00702 <h6>SDK 2.0.X onwards:</h6>
00703 - Bootloader reserves memory to put its code and data. This is no longer below 1MByte.
00704   It is recommended not to remove this memory, some applications might not work.
00705 - The image loading block is allocated at the base of the DDR2 DRAM segment if there is enough memory, or at the top available
00706   DRAM in the DDR0 segment.  It is sized based on the amount of available
00707   memory.
00708 - The linux reserved block is allocated at 0x100000 and is sized based on
00709   the amount of available memory.
00710 
00711 <h5> Configuring boot time reserved memory. </h5>
00712 
00713 The load reserved block base address and size is contolled by the
00714 <b>octeon_reserved_mem_load_base</b> and
00715 <b>octeon_reserved_mem_load_size</b>
00716 environment variables.  If these variables are not set, the defaults listed above are used.  If they are set (both must be set),
00717 then the block is allocated at the specified address and the specified size.  If octeon_reserved_mem_load_size is 0, no memory will
00718 be reserved.  When this block is allocated, the 'loadaddr' environment variable is set to the base address of this block for use
00719 in u-boot commands.
00720 
00721 The linux reserved block base address and size is contolled by the
00722 <b>octeon_reserved_mem_linux_base</b> and
00723 <b>octeon_reserved_mem_linux_size</b>
00724 environment variables. This region is not needed if Linux is not used, and will not be reserved if
00725 octeon_reserved_mem_linux_size is 0.  This reserved memory is primarily useful for systems that load simple executive
00726 and linux images at the same time on different cores.
00727 
00728 The default values will work for many configurations, but some (and in
00729 particular systems with small amounts of memory) will need these values to
00730 be tailored to the specific requirements of the system being designed.
00731 
00732 <h3> Bootloader and OCTEON executive virtual memory usage </h3>
00733 
00734 Starting in SDK 2.0, U-Boot uses the TLB and runs from virtual address
00735 0xC0000000.  This allows a single u-boot binary to be used for failsafe,
00736 normal, and remote boot.  This also allows a single u-boot binary to be
00737 burned at different addresses in flash.
00738 
00739 Before starting a simple executive application, the bootloader sets up the
00740 TLB mappings required by the application.  This includes setting up TLB
00741 mappings for code,
00742 data, stack, heap, and CVMX_SHARED variables.  These mappings are set up
00743 in virtual address range 0x1000 0000 to 0x1fff ffff.  This address range
00744 is used since it does not conflict with any 1-1 mappings.
00745 The executive uses 1-1 mappings (virtual and physical addresses the same)
00746 to avoid the need to use XKPHYS addressing modes, which requires setting bit
00747 63 of the address to access a physical address.  These 1-1 mappings are setup
00748 by the application.
00749 
00750 
00751 @section boot_process Boot process description
00752 
00753 The bootloader has been modified to support booting and starting OCTEON
00754 executive based applications on multiple cores.  This section
00755 outlines the boot process from power on to the start of the application.
00756 (Limitations of the simulation environment will be noted.)
00757 
00758 - When the OCTEON is powered on, core 0 starts execution at the reset
00759 vector, 0x1fc00000.  This address is on the OCTEON boot bus, and on a
00760 typical board flash storage will be present at this address.  The other cores
00761 remain held in reset.
00762 - u-boot starts executing from flash (or the movable boot bus region in
00763 the case of remote boot.)
00764 - If running on OCTEON II or later and the L2 cache is large enough, the U-Boot
00765   image is copied from flash to the L2 cache to speed up execution.
00766 - u-boot configures a TLB entry to map its virtual address to the physical
00767 address it is running from.  It adjusts the boot bus mappings to align its
00768 flash address as required for the TLB mappings (if booting from flash).
00769 - u-boot determines if it is booting from cache, flash or DRAM.
00770 - u-boot starts executing code, initializes the UART, and configures
00771 the DRAM controller to allow DRAM to be used (only in the non-remote boot
00772 case). (Note: the simulator does not simulate the DRAM
00773 controller, so this step is skipped.)  In order to speed boot times, oct-sim by default
00774 disables the simulator performance modeling of the flash memory.
00775 - u-boot relocates itself to DRAM, and continues executing from DRAM.
00776 - u-boot executes the default command if present - for the simulator this
00777 is the 'bootoct' command.  On hardware the bootloader displays a prompt on
00778 uart 0.
00779 
00780 
00781 <h3>Outline of simple executive application startup: </h3>
00782 
00783 - bootoct reads an OCTEON executive application ELF
00784 file the specified address (defaults to $(loadaddr)).  The ELF file is
00785 parsed, and loaded
00786 into memory, including copying the data segments for all cores that will
00787 run this application.  Memory for each core's stack and heap is also
00788 allocated.
00789 - bootoct also creates a table in memory with an entry for each core that
00790 describes the application specific initialization that it needs to
00791 perform.  This includes the TLB mappings required, application entry
00792 point, stack address/size, heap address/size.
00793 - when core 0 is ready to start the other cores, it takes them out of
00794 reset, at which point they start execution from flash at the reset
00795 exception vector.  Based on their non-zero core number, after performing
00796 the necessary per-core initialization, they jump to dram and process the
00797 table set up by core 0.  When core 0 takes the other cores out of reset it
00798 also processes its own table entry.  Core 0 also resets its cycle counter
00799 when it takes the other cores out of reset so that its cycle counter will be similar
00800 to the other cores' cycle counters.
00801 - when the processing of the table is complete, each core sets some
00802 register state for the application, and does an ERET (return from
00803 exception) to the application entry point.  The address of the table entry
00804 for the core is included in one of the registers.
00805 - the stack, heap, and argc/argv are set for the application by init
00806 code called from crt0
00807 - if the application is linked against the libcvmx.a library, the
00808 __cvmx_app_init() routine is called to initialize the simple exec.  All cores
00809 are synchronized at this time so they will start main() at the same time.
00810 - all cores enter main() at close to the same time.
00811 
00812 @section MMC_boot_process MMC boot process
00813 
00814 Booting out of MMC is either a two or three stage process depending on the
00815 size of the bootloader.  In the case of the CN61XX or CN71XX this will likely
00816 be a three stage process since the L2 cache is smaller than the bootloader.
00817 
00818 When the boot bus address line 8 is pulled up by a 10K resistor the OCTEON
00819 processor will begin executing on-chip ROM code.  This ROM code will
00820 initialize the MMC or SD device (added in CN61XX pass 1.1) and then load the
00821 first 8K at the beginning of the device into the L2 cache at address 0x81000000
00822 and begin executing it.
00823 
00824 While previously the stage 1 bootloader only loaded the stage 2 bootloader to
00825 address 0x81004000 which required a text address of 0xc0000000, the latest
00826 version automatically detects if it is linked at 0xC0000000 or 0xC0004000.  If
00827 linked at 0xC0000000 it uses a trampoline to overwrite itself with the stage 2
00828 bootloader.  This allows it to boot directly into a stage 3 bootloader on
00829 devices where the L2 cache is larger than the bootloader binary.
00830 
00831 The stage 1 bootloader will re-initialize the MMC or SD device and then look
00832 for a stage 2 bootloader. It first checks for a bootable FAT16 or FAT32
00833 partition for a file named OCTBOOT2.BIN or OCTBOOT2.BAK.  If found, it
00834 loads the file into the L2 cache beginning at address 0x81000000 and branches
00835 to the beginning of the code.  If it cannot find that file then it attempts
00836 to load the stage 2 bootloader starting at the 8K offset from the MMC device.
00837 If the failsafe GPIO is set then the FAT filesystem files will be skipped.
00838 
00839 Since the partition table is embedded in the stage 1 bootloader it is possible
00840 to hard-code a DOS partition table entry into it by modifying start.S.
00841 
00842 The FAT partition must be marked as bootable by FDISK and must have a valid
00843 logial block address.  The stage 1 bootloader ignores the old cylinder, head,
00844 sector entry.
00845 
00846 A tool has been created in order to update the stage 1 and stage 2 bootloaders
00847 called write_stage1 under bootloader/tools.  This will overwrite the stage 1
00848 and stage 2 bootloaders and will preserve the partition table.  Before using
00849 write_stage1 run make in the bootloader/tools directory.
00850 
00851 It is safe to use the Linux fdisk tool in order to partition the MMC or SD
00852 device.  NOTE: make sure that none of the partitions include the first 8K or
00853 the space required for the stage 2 bootloader if that is also installed after
00854 the stage 1 bootloader.  Generally this is not a problem with fdisk since the
00855 minimum starting block is typically 2048, reserving the first 1MB.  If an older
00856 version of fdisk is used type the 'u' command to change the units from C/H/S to
00857 LBA sectors.  Older versions of fdisk also will default to using a smaller
00858 starting sector.  If this is the case, set the starting sector to 2048 for the
00859 first partition.
00860 
00861 Use the 'a' command in fdisk to mark the FAT partition as bootable.
00862 NOTE: do not use a FAT12 partition.  FAT12 is not supported.
00863 
00864 The provided stage 2 bootloader is generic and uses the TLV information on
00865 the board to detect the board type in order to initialize the DRAM.  It
00866 provides minimal functionality in order to load a stage 3 bootloader so that it
00867 can fit entirely within the L2 cache.  If the stage 3 bootloader is corrupted
00868 or not present it is possible to use the loady or loadb command to load
00869 the stage 3 bootloader over the serial port.  In minicom, loady is the preferred
00870 method and uses y-modem.
00871 
00872 The stage 3 bootloader is typically stored on a filesystem on the MMC device.
00873 To load and execute the stage 3 bootloader the following commands should
00874 be executed:
00875 
00876 @verbatim
00877 fatload mmc 0 0x81000000 u-boot-octeon_stage3_name.bin
00878 go 0x81000000
00879 @endverbatim
00880 
00881 Alternatively, the following command may be used:
00882 
00883 @verbatim
00884 bootstage3
00885 @endverbatim
00886 
00887 @section SPI_boot_process SPI boot process
00888 The SPI boot process consists of on-chip ROM loading the first 8K from the SPI
00889 EEPROM or flash device.
00890 
00891 A three stage boot process is used, similar to how eMMC is booted.
00892 
00893 The stage 1 bootloader named spi-boot.bin is written to the very beginning
00894 of the SPI NOR flash.  This bootloader will scan the SPI NOR for a stage 2
00895 bootloader and load it to address 0x81000000 using a trampoline to overwrite
00896 itself. The stage 2 bootloader should be marked as a stage 2 bootloader in the
00897 header and it should be installed on a page-sized boundary starting at offset
00898 0x10000.
00899 
00900 The stage 2 bootloader, which must be small enough to fit in L2 cache will
00901 initialize DRAM then search for and load the stage 3 bootloader to address
00902 0x81000000 and execute it.  Two copies of the stage 3 bootloader are supported
00903 and the second copy will be loaded unless the failsafe GPIO setting is set.
00904 
00905 The stage 3 bootloader should be located after the stage 2 bootloader and
00906 reside on a 64K boundary.
00907 
00908 @section Octeon_III_NAND_boot_process Octeon III NAND boot process
00909 The Octeon CN70XX supports NAND with a new hardware BCH engine to handle
00910 multi-bit NAND ECC.  Unlike previous Octeon models, however, the boot process
00911 must start with either a SPI EEPROM or a SPI NOR.  The SPI EEPROM must be a
00912 minimum of 32K with a 64K device being recommended.
00913 
00914 The NAND boot process consist of several stages. Octeon will read the first 8K
00915 out of the SPI EEPROM and begin execution.  Since the NAND bootloader requires
00916 more than 8K, the first stage looks for and loads the NAND stage 1.5 bootloader
00917 immediately following the SPI stage 1 bootloader.
00918 
00919 The stage 1.5 bootloader begins scanning the NAND device looking for a valid
00920 bootloader starting at the beginning of the NAND device.  Bad and corrupt blocks
00921 are automatically skipped and the ECC is applied to each page read.  Once the
00922 stage 2 bootloader is loaded into memory a trampoline is used to begin execution
00923 at address 0x81000000 to start the stage 2 bootloader.
00924 
00925 The stage 2 bootloader initializes DRAM and searches for and loads the final
00926 stage 3 bootloader into memory and transfers execution to it.
00927 
00928 Unlike earlier Octeon devices, the new stage 1.5 bootloader is fully compatible
00929 with the ECC and layout used by both U-Boot and Linux.
00930 
00931 The stage 1 and 1.5 bootloader code is contained under bootloader/nand2-boot.
00932 By default it is configured to execute out of a SPI EEPROM and not a SPI NOR
00933 flash since that is most likely what customers will use.  If a SPI NOR device
00934 is used, for example on the SFF7000 board, then spi-config.h will need to be
00935 modified to define CONFIG_SPI_NOR and comment out the define for
00936 CONFIG_SPI_EEPROM_M95XXX.
00937 
00938 Running make will build both the stage 1 and stage 1.5 bootloaders and
00939 create a file called spi-combined.bin which contains both bootloaders.
00940 
00941 With a SPI EEPROM the following commands will update the stage 1 and 1.5
00942 bootloaders:
00943 
00944 @verbatim
00945 # tftp 0 spi-combined.bin
00946 # spieeprom write $(fileaddr) 0 $(filesize)
00947 @endverbatim
00948 
00949 If a SPI NOR flash is used then the following commands should be used:
00950 
00951 @verbatim
00952 # tftp 0 spi-combined.bin
00953 # sf probe
00954 # sf update $(fileaddr) 0 $(filesize)
00955 @endverbatim
00956 
00957 The stage 2 and final stage bootloaders can be written using the bootloaderupdate
00958 command as follows:
00959 
00960 @verbatim
00961 # tftp 0 u-boot-octeon_generic_nand2_stage2.bin
00962 # bootloaderupdate nand
00963 # tftp 0 u-boot-octeon_board.bin
00964 # bootloaderupdate nand
00965 @endverbatim
00966 
00967 If there are any problems the nand commands can be used:
00968 
00969 @verbatim
00970 # tftp 0 u-boot-octeon_generic_nand2_stage2.bin
00971 # nand erase 0 $(filesize)
00972 # nand write $(fileaddr) 0 $(filesize)
00973 # tftp 0 u-boot-octeon_boardname.bin
00974 # nand erase 0x100000 $(filesize)
00975 # nand write $(fileaddr) 0x100000 $(filesize)
00976 @endverbatim
00977 
00978 @section modifting_mmc_stage1 Modifying the stage 1 eMMC bootloader
00979 Most of the configurable parameters for the stage 1 bootloader can be
00980 found in bootloader/emmc-boot/stage1/config.h.
00981 - @b UART_PORT UART port number
00982 - @b UART_BAUD_RATE baud rate to initialize the UART to
00983 - @b STAGE1_START_STRING string displayed just before executing any C code
00984 - @b STAGE1_BOOTLOADER_SIZE Do not change this.
00985 - @b STAGE2_DRAM_LOAD_ADDR Starting address to load the stage 2 bootloader
00986 - @b STAGE2_START_ADDRESS Address to begin executing in the stage 2 bootloader
00987 - @b STAGE2_DRAM_SIZE Amount of memory used for the stage 2 bootloader.
00988 NOTE: The stage 1 bootloader does not verify if the stage 2 bootloader exceeds
00989 this size.
00990 - @b STAGE_2_FILENAME File name to use for the stage to bootloader.  The file
00991 name must be 11 characters in length.  For a normal 8.3 DOS filename, pad
00992 the 8 character part out with spaces then add the three letter extension.  Use
00993 upper-case characters.
00994 
00995 - @b STAGE2_BACKUP_FILENAME Backup file name to use if the primary stage 2
00996 bootloader fails.
00997 - @b STAGE2_ENV_FILENAME Environment filename loaded into memory.  Not currently
00998 supported.
00999 - @b STAGE1_VALIDATE_STAGE2_CRC Define this to verify the stage 2 bootloader CRC.
01000 - @b MMC_MAX_WIDTH Maximum width of MMC device supported
01001 - @b MMC_SET_BLOCKLEN Sets the block length before read operations.  Not needed
01002 and not compatible with some MMC devices.
01003 - @b STAGE1_RESET_MMC Define this to reset the MMC device before executing the
01004 stage 2 bootloader.
01005 - @b STAGE_2_LAST_FAILSAFE Define this to search for a stage 2 bootloader
01006 immediately following the stage 1 bootloader at the beginning of the MMC device
01007 if no stage 2 bootloader is found in a FAT partition.
01008 - @b STAGE_2_LAST_FAILSAFE_START_SECTOR Starting sector to use for loading the
01009 stage 2 bootloader.
01010 - @b MAX_FAT_RETRIES Maximum number of retries to load a stage 2 bootloader
01011 from the FAT filesystem.  This should be a multiple of four.  First it tries
01012 to load the standard stage 2 using the primary FAT table, then it tries the
01013 backup stage 2 with the primary FAT table.  Next it tries the primary and
01014 backup stage 2 bootloaders using the backup FAT table before switching back to
01015 the primary FAT table.
01016 - @b MMC_MIN_SPEED Minimum speed when starting MMC negotiation.  This must
01017 not exceed 400KHz.
01018 - @b MMC_MAX_SPEED Maximum speed for the MMC bus.  It is best not to exceed
01019 20MHz for external MMC cards although it has been tested at speeds up to 52MHz.
01020 
01021 @section Environment Variable When Booting via MMC/SD
01022 
01023 It is now possible for the stage 1 bootloader to load the environment variables
01024 for the stage 2 bootloader. In order to do this, issue the following commands
01025 to save the environment variables:
01026 
01027 @verbatim
01028 env export -c -s 0x1000 0x20000000
01029 fatwrite mmc 0 0x20000000 octboot2.env 0x1000
01030 @endverbatim
01031 
01032 @section building_u-boot Building u-boot
01033 To rebuild u-boot for the ebb6800 board, run the following commands in
01034 the u-boot directory: @verbatim
01035 $ make distclean
01036 $ make octeon_ebb6800_config
01037 $ make
01038 @endverbatim
01039 The 'octeon_ebb6800_config' target only needs to be made once.  The file
01040 'u-boot-octeon_ebb6800.bin' is the binary image of the bootloader,
01041 suitable for burning to the boot flash on the board.  The process is same
01042 for other evaluation boards - only the configuration and file names are different.
01043 
01044 To rebuild for the simulator, the 'octeon_sim_config' configuration target
01045 needs to be made, and the 'u-boot-octeon_sim.bin' produced. Copy the built
01046 bootloader to $OCTEON_ROOT/target/bin directory.
01047 
01048 <h2>Building bootloader without USB Support</h2>
01049 The bootloader is now capable of recognizing USB devices connected to the board.
01050 It can also load applications from USB devices to memory. The USB support is
01051 enabled by default in the bootloader. To disable USB support in bootloader for
01052 an EBB6100 board, look for CONFIG_OCTEON_USB_OCTEON2 in include/configs/octeon_ebh6100.h
01053 file and disable all the macros as per the comments in the file. Then re-build
01054 the bootloader using the following commands:
01055 @verbatim
01056 $ vi include/configs/octeon_ebb6100.h  // make the changes and save
01057 $ make clean
01058 $ make octeon_ebb6100_config
01059 $ make
01060 @endverbatim
01061 
01062 Follow the instructions mentioned in @ref updating_u-boot to update this newly built
01063 bootloader.
01064 
01065 @section updating_u-boot Updating u-boot on an evaluation board
01066 There are two bootloader images burned into the flash on OCTEON evaluation
01067 boards - failsafe and normal. The failsafe image
01068 is programmed by Cavium before the board is shipped and should not
01069 be updated in the field.  The failsafe image provides a means
01070 to recover from a failed bootloader update. The board is shipped with the current
01071 normal bootloader image, and this image is field upgradable.
01072 NOTE: From SDK-2.0.X release onwards, same bootloader image is used in failsafe
01073       and normal mode.
01074 
01075 <h3>To upgrade the bootloader with NOR FLASH</h3>
01076 <b>To upgrade bootloader from SDK-1.8.X or SDK-1.9.X release to SDK-2.0.X release</b>
01077 - Load the new bootloader to the address $(loadaddr) from compactflash, usb, network, etc.
01078 - Find the size of the new bootloader by invoking, for example on ebb6300 board
01079 @code
01080   Octeon ebb6300# printenv filesize
01081   filesize=DA480
01082 @endcode
01083 
01084   Round the size up to the nearest 0x10000 bytes and pass it to uboot_flash_size
01085   environment variable.
01086 @code
01087   setenv uboot_flash_size 0xe0000
01088 @endcode
01089 
01090 - burn the new image with the command:
01091 @code
01092   run bootloader_flash_update; reset
01093   saveenv; reset
01094 @endcode
01095 
01096 <b>To upgrade bootloader from SDK-2.X.X to modified version </b>
01097 - Load the new bootloader to the address $(loadaddr) from compactflash, usb, network, etc.
01098 - burn the new image with the command:
01099 @code
01100     bootloaderupdate
01101 @endcode
01102 This command reads the bootloader image from DRAM (previously loaded via TFTP,
01103 compact flash, SD card or usb) and burns it onto the flash location the
01104 executable is built at. This command burns the bootloader to the first
01105 available sector aligned segment on the flash, if the flash location the
01106 executable is built at is used by failsafe bootloader. This removes the limit
01107 on the size of the bootloader.  Both failsafe and normal bootloader images have
01108 an embedded header that describes the image and which is used by this command to
01109 relocate the image.  Because of this embedded header in the image, the failsafe
01110 bootloader is incompatible with the previously released bootloaders (SDK-1.9.X
01111 and older).
01112 
01113 To force the bootloader to be updated in NAND use the following command:
01114 @code
01115     bootloaderupdate nand
01116 @endcode
01117 
01118 To force the bootloader to be updated in SPI use the following command:
01119 @code
01120     bootloaderupdate spi
01121 @endcode
01122 
01123 - reset the board.  The new bootloader should boot.
01124 
01125 <h3>Updating a SPI bootloader</h3>
01126 There are three components to the SPI bootloader:
01127   (1) Stage 1 bootloader, typically named spi-boot.bin
01128   (2) Stage 2 bootloader, typically named u-boot-octeon_generic_spi_stage2.bin
01129       or u-boot-octeon_generic_cn70xx_spi_stage2.bin
01130   (3) Stage 3 bootloader
01131 
01132 If the L2 cache is large enough, for example on the CN73XX and CN78XX then the
01133 stage 2 bootloader is not required.
01134 
01135 To write the stage 1 bootloader use the following commands:
01136 @code
01137 # tftp 0 spi-combined.bin
01138 # bootloaderupdate spi
01139 @endcode
01140 
01141 or alternatively:
01142 @code
01143 # sf probe
01144 # sf update $(fileaddr) 0 $(filesize)
01145 @endcode
01146 
01147 Currently only a single copy of the stage 2 bootloader is supported by the SPI
01148 stage 1 bootloader.  A future release will add support for both a failsafe as
01149 well as a normal bootloader.  If a stage 2 and stage 3 bootloader are used, the
01150 stage 2 bootloader supports both a failsafe and standard stage 3 bootloader.
01151 
01152 The stage 2 bootloader is typically installed at offset 0x10000 (64K) in the
01153 SPI NOR and the environment is typically stored at offset 0xe000 (56K) in the
01154 SPI NOR.  If a stage 3 bootloader is installed, the failsafe will be installed
01155 at the next 64K boundary after the stage 2 bootloader.
01156 
01157 To write the failsafe and standard stage 2 bootloaders use the following
01158 commands:
01159 @code
01160 # tftp 0 u-boot-octeon_generic_cn70xx_spi_stage2.bin
01161 # bootloaderupdate spi
01162 @endcode
01163 
01164 Alternatively, if for some reason that should fail:
01165 
01166 @code
01167 # sf update $(fileaddr) 0x10000 $(filesize)
01168 @endcode
01169 
01170 Two copies of the stage 3 bootloader are also supported for both a failsafe and
01171 non-failsafe.
01172 
01173 @code
01174 # tftp 0 u-boot-octeon_boardname.bin
01175 # bootloaderupdate spi
01176 @endcode
01177 
01178 Or alternatively:
01179 @code
01180 # sf update $(fileaddr) 0x100000 $(filesize)
01181 # sf update $(fileaddr) 0x280000 $(filesize)
01182 @endcode
01183 
01184 The last offsets shown, 0x100000 and 0x280000 must be such that they do not
01185 overwrite the stage 2 bootloaders.  Any starting offsets should be rounded up
01186 to the next 64K offset.
01187 
01188 There is also some initial support for the bootloaderupdate command but this
01189 support has not been thoroughly tested and may contain bugs.  To use the
01190 bootloaderupdate command use the following commands:
01191 
01192 @code
01193 # tftp 0 u-boot-octeon_generic_spi_stage2.bin
01194 # bootloaderupdate spi
01195 # tftp 0 u-boot-octeon_boardname.bin
01196 # bootloaderupdate spi
01197 @endcode
01198 
01199 The bootloaderupdate command will automatically detect if the bootloader is a
01200 stage 1, stage 2 or stage 3 bootloader.
01201 
01202 If there are problems then the sf erase command can be used then the bootloaderupdate
01203 command should work properly, or if not, the bootloader can be updated manually.
01204 
01205 <h3>Old style (SDK 1.9.X and older) bootloader updates </h3>
01206 
01207 To upgrade the bootloader:
01208 - put the new bootloader image onto a compact flash card, insert the card into
01209 the OCTEON board, and turn the board on.
01210 - load the image into dram with the command:
01211 @code
01212      fatload ide 0 $(loadaddr) image-filename
01213 @endcode
01214 - burn the new image with the command:
01215 @code
01216     run bootloader_flash_update
01217 @endcode
01218 Since the failsafe bootloader is not field upgraded, this method may be
01219 required when using the failsafe image.  This method can be used to write
01220 u-boot images with the header (new in 1.9), as the header is embedded
01221 in the binary image.
01222 
01223 Note: The size of the bootloader exceeds the default flash size when the bootloader
01224 is built with USB support or PCI support, adjust uboot_flash_size before invoking
01225 'run bootloader_flash_update', as mentioned below:
01226 @code
01227     fatload ide 0 $(loadaddr) image-file
01228     setenv uboot_flash_size 0x90000
01229     run bootloader_flash_update
01230 @endcode
01231 Always make sure the value of uboot_flash_size returned by the present bootloader
01232 is greater than the size of the bootloader that is being updated. And also make sure
01233 the size of the bootloader passed to 'uboot_flash_size' is rounded to the next
01234 0x10000 bytes.
01235 
01236 <h3>Recovering from a failed bootloader update </h3>
01237 The failsafe bootloader image is not modified when updating the normal
01238 bootloader image.  If the normal image update fails, the failsafe bootloader
01239 can be used to update the normal bootloader image.
01240 The following instructions apply to the CN38XX-EVB-NIC4 board only.
01241 To use the failsafe bootloader image to update the normal image:
01242 - flip switch 1 on the SW9 on Rev 4 boards (SW8 on rev 3 boards) switch pack to 'off'.  This is GPIO 0, and an LED
01243 should come on indicating that the GPIO line is now high.  (The switch polarity
01244 is reversed.)
01245 - reset the board.  The failsafe bootloader image should now boot.  The bootloader
01246 prompt should identify itself as the failsafe bootloader.
01247 - follow the directions in the section above describing the bootloader update
01248 - power board off, return switch 1 of the SW9 on Rev 4 boards (SW8 on rev 3 boards) switch pack to 'on', and turn
01249 the board on.  The new bootloader image should now boot.
01250 
01251 <h3>To upgrade the bootloader with SPI NOR FLASH</h3>
01252 The SPI boot process requires a multi-stage boot process, either two or three
01253 stages depending on the size of the L2 cache of the Octeon processor.
01254 
01255 Currently only CN70XX/CN71XX requires a three-stage boot process.
01256 
01257 The first stage is a file called @code spi-boot.bin @endcode . This file looks
01258 for a valid stage 2 bootloader starting at offset 0x10000 (64KB) and loads it
01259 into the L2 cache at address 0x81000000 and transfers control to the stage 2
01260 bootloader. For CN73XX, CN78XX and CNF75XX the stage 2 bootloader is the final
01261 stage.  For CN70XX, however, due to limitations of the L2 cache size, a
01262 stage 2 bootloader is typically required.
01263 
01264 If the board has a TLV EEPROM then the generic SPI stage 2 bootloader can be
01265 used, otherwise a custom stage 2 bootloader for that particular board is
01266 required.
01267 
01268 The stage 2 bootloader will initialize DDR memory then load a stage 3 bootloader
01269 into memory and transfer control to the stage 3 bootloader. If the SPI nor is
01270 large enough there may be both a failsafe and a standard stage 3 bootloader.
01271 In this case, the failsafe GPIO (typically 0) is checked to see if the standard
01272 or failsafe bootloader should be loaded and control is transferred to that
01273 bootloader.
01274 
01275 <h4>Upgrading the SPI bootloaders</h4>.
01276 The bootloaderupdate command has been enhanced in order to support SPI NOR.
01277 The command will automatically detect which bootloader is to be installed
01278 and will install it at the appropriate location in the SPI NOR.  The stage 1
01279 bootloader is always installed at offset 0 and the stage 2 is typically
01280 installed at offset 0x10000 (64K).
01281 
01282 To update the stage 1 bootloader use either tftp, fatload or some other command
01283 to load the spi-boot.bin file into memory then issue the following command:
01284 
01285 @code
01286 # bootloaderupdate spi
01287 @endcode
01288 
01289 If the board lacks parallel NOR flash then the "spi" parameter may be ommitted.
01290 
01291 To update the stage 2 bootloader for a three-stage boot process the same command
01292 may be used.  To update the failsafe stage 3 bootloader, use the
01293 following command:
01294 
01295 @code
01296 # bootloaderupdate spi failsafe
01297 @endcode
01298 
01299 Updating the non-failsafe stage 3 bootloader uses the following command, where
01300 the "spi" paramter may be ommitted if the board lacks a parallel NOR flash.
01301 
01302 @code
01303 # bootloaderupdate spi
01304 @endcode
01305 
01306 The bootloaderupdate command will issue a warning if the new bootloader is
01307 larger than the old bootloader causing it to overwrite the beginning of
01308 the next bootloader.  For example, if the new stage 2 bootloader is bigger than
01309 the previous one, it may be required to update the stage 3 failsafe and normal
01310 bootloader. Similarly, if the new stage 3 failsafe bootloader overwrites the
01311 standard bootloader it will be required that the standard bootloader also be
01312 updated.
01313 
01314 Currently the stage 1 bootloader lacks support for supporting a standard and
01315 failsafe stage 2 or final stage bootloader.  Future releases of this SDK will
01316 add this capability.
01317 
01318 Since this will require a larger stage 1 bootloader, the stage 1 will be broken
01319 down into two parts.  The first 56-60K should always be reserved for the stage
01320 1 bootloader in the SPI NOR flash, leaving 4-8K for environment variables to
01321 be stored before the stage 2 bootloader.
01322 
01323 
01324 @section board_support Supporting new boards (porting)
01325 
01326 It is very straightforward to add support for a new board to u-boot.  Hacking an existing
01327 board configuration will cause problems, as the board type is used in many places to determine
01328 how things should be configured.  The following is an outline of how to add support for a new board to u-boot.
01329 
01330 
01331 - Add new board type to cvmx-app-init.h.  This should be added to the CVMX_BOARD_TYPE_CUST_PRIVATE_* section.
01332   This range is reserved for private use by customers, so the standard SDK will never use this range.
01333 - Add board config file to u-boot/include/configs.  Start out by copying an existing configuration.
01334   Update prompt string, dram timing, and other configuration settings that differ from the source of the copy.
01335 - add board directory to u-boot/board/octeon directory.  Again, start out by copying/renaming an existing configuration.
01336   Be sure to update setting of board type in these files, and to remove any code that doesn't apply to the new board.
01337 - add config targets to u-boot/boards.cfg.
01338 - add new board memory configuration to u-boot/arch/mips/cpu/lib_octeon_shared.c
01339 - add board specific configuration to cvmx-helper-board.c.  U-boot, the simple executive, and Linux all use this file
01340   to get board specific configuration information.
01341 
01342 
01343 
01344 Cavium evaluation boards have some features (MCU and PAL for controlling clocks and voltages )
01345 that provide flexible configuration that are usually not present on production boards.  The values
01346 that are determined from these should be hard coded for boards that do not have them.  Also, all OCTEON
01347 evaluation boards have a TWSI eeprom that stores board specific information such as serial number and MAC
01348 addresses.  If this eeprom is missing from production boards then other means will need to be used to
01349 store this information.
01350 
01351 @section se_api Simple Executive API
01352 Support has been added to support a Simple Executive API for SE applications to
01353 allow simple executive applications to read U-Boot environment variables as
01354 well as simple file I/O.  The file I/O should be limited to small files that
01355 are 64K or smaller due to the fact that there is an internal 64K bounce buffer
01356 used in U-Boot.  File write operations beyond 64K are not supported and read
01357 operations will become increasingly slow since each read past 64K will require
01358 re-reading the entire file up to that point.  For example, reading a 256K file
01359 will cause the bootloader to read 64K, then 128K, then 192K then 256K.  See the
01360 uboot-seapi example program on its use.  Note that most bootloaders have this
01361 option disabled.
01362 
01363 To enable this API for SE applications, define CONFIG_OCTEON_SE_NAPI in the
01364 board's  configuration .h file under include/configs.
01365 
01366 @section limitations Limitations
01367 
01368 - U-boot is a 32 bit application, meaning pointers are 32 bits.  This
01369 restricts what addresses U-boot can run from and what memory it has easy
01370 access to.  Several assembly routines have been added to allow access to
01371 hardware units, such as the UART.
01372 
01373 - OCTEON executive applications do not support returning to the bootloader
01374 on application completion.
01375 
01376 @section serial_config
01377 The u-boot 'loadb' command supports serial download using the kermit
01378 protocol, although it only supports a limited
01379 subset of the protocol.  The following options should be set in the
01380 .kermrc file for use with u-boot:
01381 
01382 @code
01383 set modem type none
01384 set line /dev/ttyUSB0  #Change this to match the serial device
01385 set speed 115200
01386 #set speed 460800   # Many USB serial adapters support 460800
01387 set streaming off
01388 set prefixing all
01389 set flow xon/xoff
01390 set carrier-watch off
01391 robust
01392 
01393 Many USB serial adapters support 460800 bps, so this can be a very quick
01394 way to load small files.  This is especially useful during early board
01395 bringup when the UART may be the only way to load code.  Serial download
01396 along with a failsafe bootloader can greatly speed up bootloader
01397 development on new boards.
01398 
01399 @endcode
01400 
01401 @section console_config
