01402 The u-boot console supports multiple consoles being active simultaneously on
01403 boards that support PCI or PCIE target support.  By default, the PCI console
01404 will be active for stdin only.  This is due to the fact that stdout will block
01405 if no PCI console is connected.
01406 
01407 To enable the PCI console output, at any time use the following commands:
01408 
01409 @code
01410 setenv stdin serial,pci,bootoct
01411 setenv stdout serial,pci
01412 setenv stderr serial,pci
01413 @endcode
01414 
01415 This enables output to be sent to both the serial console and the pci console.
01416 For output to the pci console only, remove serial.
01417 
01418 stdin by default supports serial, pci, and bootoct.  bootoct is used by a number
01419 of utilities like oct-pci-bootcmd, oct-pci-load and several others.  It is an
01420 alternate method of entering commands that will likely go away in the near future
01421 in favor of the PCI console.
01422 
01423 @section u-boot_applications
01424 U-Boot supports native applications which are binaries that are able to call
01425 a number of exported functions.  This support has been added to the OCTEON
01426 U-Boot but there are a number of differences in the way that it works.
01427 Most of these differences are hidden from both the user and the developer.
01428 
01429 For one thing, U-Boot applications run in virtual memory like U-Boot itself.
01430 Unlike U-Boot, however, the memory address space is different.
01431 
01432 When the go command is used to start a native application, the go command first
01433 checks to see if the special U-Boot native application header is present or
01434 not.  The header contains information such as the virtual address where the
01435 application starts and the start and end addresses of the various segments.
01436 
01437 If it is found then it will attempt to allocate memory, first from
01438 memory normally unavailable to 32-bit applications if possible.  A named block
01439 named "u-boot-app" is used.
01440 
01441 The go command figures out the amount of space needed to hold the entire
01442 application including its BSS segment and rounds it up to a page size where
01443 the entire application will fit in either one or two pages.  If, for example,
01444 an application is 17,992 bytes then two 16K pages will be used and 32K will be
01445 allocated.
01446 
01447 Next the memory is mapped to the virtual address specified in the header which
01448 is typically 0xD0000000.  Note that the starting virtual address must not
01449 cross a page boundary and it must not overlap with U-Boot.  Currently addresses
01450 in the range of 0xC0100000 through DFFFF000 are supported though the default
01451 address of 0xD0000000 provides the least chance of any issues.
01452 
01453 The application, up until the bss segment, is copied into the virtual memory
01454 and the bss segment is initialized to zero.
01455 
01456 Several fields in the application header are filled in by U-Boot to help assist
01457 the application.
01458 
01459 Normally the application would start to search for a special signature for
01460 the native API starting at the stack pointer.  Since this is limited to 3MB it
01461 may not cover the heap and find the data structure.  Due to this, the address
01462 of the data structure is copied into the application header and the starting
01463 search location is set to this address.
01464 
01465 There are also version fields, both for the application and the bootloader to
01466 support backward and forward compatibility.
01467 
01468 After the application returns control back to U-Boot the virtual to physical
01469 mapping is removed and the memory block is freed.
01470 
01471 All of this support is handled under the covers so it should be transparent to
01472 both the U-Boot user and the application developer.  The only other thing to be
01473 aware of is that like U-Boot memory addresses are not physical addresses.
01474 
01475 Memory allocated using malloc will be allocated from U-Boot's heap which is
01476 typically initialized to have 12MB available.  Similarly, the application
01477 inherits U-Boot's stack.  The cvmx_bootmem allocation routines are safe to use
01478 but should be freed before exiting.
01479 
01480 Before exiting it is imparative that U-Boot not have any pointers or references
01481 to memory locations within the app since as soon as it exits the virtual
01482 mapping will disappear.  This should make it easy to discover if any crashes
01483 are caused due to this.
01484 
01485 All applications should use the mips-octeon.lds linker script found in the
01486 examples/api and examples/standalone directories.  They also must use the crt0.S
01487 file in examples/api as well since this contains all of the header and support
01488 code.  The examples/api/octeon.c file provides several library files that
01489 are missing due to architectural specific versions of memcmp, memset, memcpy,
01490 hw_watchdog_reset, get_tbclk and crc32.
01491 
01492 In order to enable the native API support add
01493 @code
01494 #define CONFIG_API
01495 @endcode
01496 to the board configuration header file.
01497 
01498 Currently it is only enabled in the simulator and the Embedded Planet EP6300C
01499 board.  This may be enabled in additional boards in the future.  In order to
01500 use it with the demo application use the following command:
01501 
01502 @code
01503 oct-sim examples/api/demo.bin -noperf -uart0=1234 -quiet
01504 @endcode
01505 
01506 Then telnet to port 1234.  Press return immediately to prevent it from
01507 automatically starting the application then type:
01508 
01509 @code
01510 go 0x10000000
01511 @endcode
01512 
01513 This will start the demo application.  Failure to press ENTER early enough will
01514 cause U-Boot to crash since demo.bin is not compatible with simple exec.
01515 
01516 If support is added to a board the command to start the application is:
01517 
01518 @code
01519 go $(fileaddr)
01520 @endcode
01521 
01522 Do not specify the virtual address in the go command.  The virtual address will
01523 be automatically calculated from the header.
01524 */
